title: Network epistemology in practice
descriptions:
This grant proposal seeks to explore the concept of network epistemology in the context of particle physics research at the European Center for Nuclear Research (CERN). The project will focus on understanding knowledge generation and validation in large scientific collaborations, characterizing collective research processes through analysis of internal communication, and reconstructing this communication from born-digital documents. By delving into the internal communication channels such as e-mails and internal wiki pages, the study aims to develop historiographic guidelines for future research and contribute to the philosophy of collective knowledge generation.

Using digital humanities tools and computational methods, this project will offer methodological innovations in capturing and analyzing large-scale research processes for epistemological purposes. The outcomes of this research will include historiographic guidelines for studies based on born-digital sources and practical strategies for best practices in the history and philosophy of science. By adapting theoretical models of network epistemology to real-world scientific collaborations, this project will offer valuable insights into the dynamics of knowledge creation within interdisciplinary research environments. Ultimately, this research will shed light on the intricate processes of knowledge production and validation in scientific communities, providing a foundation for future studies in the history and philosophy of science.

The proposed project, "Network epistemology in practice," aims to explore knowledge generation and validation within large scientific collaborations, focusing on particle physics at CERN. By analyzing internal communication from born-digital documents such as e-mails and internal wiki pages, the project seeks to understand collective research processes and develop historiographic guidelines for future studies. Through the case study of CERN, the project will contribute to the philosophy of collective knowledge generation and adapt theoretical models of network epistemology.

Utilizing digital humanities tools and computational methods, the project will provide methodological innovations for capturing and analyzing complex research processes for epistemological analysis. The outcomes of the project will include historiographic guidelines for studies based on born-digital sources and practical strategies for best practices in the history and philosophy of science.

Overall, this project offers a unique opportunity to delve into the dynamics of knowledge production in large scientific collaborations, shedding light on the intricate processes of validation and communication that underpin collective research efforts. By bridging the gap between history, philosophy, and digital tools, this project has the potential to significantly advance our understanding of network epistemology in practice.

The proposed project, "Network epistemology in practice," seeks to explore the history and philosophy of science through a focus on particle physics at CERN. Using digital humanities tools, the project aims to understand knowledge generation and validation in large scientific collaborations by analyzing internal communication within the European Center for Nuclear Research. The objectives include characterizing collective research processes, reconstructing internal communication from born-digital documents, developing historiographic guidelines, and contributing to the philosophy of collective knowledge generation.

By studying source materials such as e-mails and internal wiki pages, the project will provide historiographic guidelines for future studies based on born-digital sources and offer practical strategies for best practices in the history and philosophy of science. Methodological innovations will include the application of digital tools and computational methods to capture large-scale, complex research processes for epistemological analysis. Ultimately, this project aims to adapt theoretical models of network epistemology to better understand how knowledge is produced and validated in collaborative scientific endeavors. Through its interdisciplinary approach, this project has the potential to make significant contributions to both the fields of history and philosophy of science.
